timeline.message: categorize sign up and sign in errors
Centralized error mapping and refactored recovery messages

timeline.body:
You could further simplify your code in the plugin, by providing a default exception, here:
```suggestion
        return new AuthException(fallbackMessage, error, "See attached exception for more details.");
```
Then, you'd only need to pass in an additional `fallbackMessage` when you call the lookup:
```java
AuthException mapped =
    CognitoAuthExceptionConverter.lookup("Fallback message for some situation, here.", error);
```

Note: this is just a suggestion. You can choose not to do this.
timeline.bodyHTML:
You could further simplify your code in the plugin, by providing a default exception, here:

Suggested change
return null;
return new AuthException(fallbackMessage, error, "See attached exception for more details.");

Then, you'd only need to pass in an additional fallbackMessage when you call the lookup:

AuthException mapped =
    CognitoAuthExceptionConverter.lookup("Fallback message for some situation, here.", error);

Note: this is just a suggestion. You can choose not to do this.
timeline.author: jamesonwilliams

replies.bodyText: This is a very good suggestion!
replies.author: changxu0306

timeline.author: jamesonwilliams

timeline.body: This type of exception is also implementation specific. (The Auth _category_ doesn't need to involved AWS Lambda, necessarily.) I'd recommend to remove this `LambdaException` entirely.
timeline.bodyText: This type of exception is also implementation specific. (The Auth category doesn't need to involved AWS Lambda, necessarily.) I'd recommend to remove this LambdaException entirely.
timeline.bodyHTML: This type of exception is also implementation specific. (The Auth category doesn't need to involved AWS Lambda, necessarily.) I'd recommend to remove this LambdaException entirely.
timeline.author: jamesonwilliams

timeline.body: Mentions two details of the implementation -- Cognito, Lambda. That's fine for the _plugin_, but not the category, which is abstract.
timeline.bodyText: Mentions two details of the implementation -- Cognito, Lambda. That's fine for the plugin, but not the category, which is abstract.
timeline.bodyHTML: Mentions two details of the implementation -- Cognito, Lambda. That's fine for the plugin, but not the category, which is abstract.

timeline.message: remove unused classes, ge rid of plugin specific info in core

timeline.body: A bit of nit picking but it was counter intuitive to me seeing this used with the string as the first parameter. It makes it seem like the string is what you're looking up. I think it'd be more intuitive to change the order of these parameters to make clear you're looking up the error and then specifying what message to use. You can use Android Studio to easily refactor the parameter order without having to worry about changing all the places this is used manually.
timeline.bodyText: A bit of nit picking but it was counter intuitive to me seeing this used with the string as the first parameter. It makes it seem like the string is what you're looking up. You can use Android Studio to easily refactor the parameter order without having to worry about changing all the places this is used manually.

You can use Android Studio to easily refactor the parameter order without having to worry about changing all the places this is used manually.

replies.bodyText: I really like this detailed suggestion😄 Yeah it's just like reading a book and the order of parameters matters a lot.

timeline.body:
Prefix with `@NonNull` to let developers know that this operation always returns a non-null exception.
The parameters should also have `@NonNull` and/or `@Nullable` tags.

The above practice should be used for every publicly exposed methods throughout the repo :)
timeline.bodyText:
Prefix with @NonNull to let developers know that this operation always returns a non-null exception.
The parameters should also have @NonNull and/or @Nullable tags.
The above practice should be used for every publicly exposed methods throughout the repo :)
